text: Glucocorticoid - induced cell death requires autoinduction of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in human leukemic T cells .

In contrast to the negative autoregulation of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) expression seen in most cells and tissues , <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is positively autoregulated in human leukemic T cells and in other cells sensitive to glucocorticoid - induced cell death .

To determine whether positive autoregulation is a necessary component of glucocorticoid - induced cell death , a wild-type <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene under the control of a tetracycline - regulated promoter was stably transfected into glucocorticoid - resistant cells lacking endogenous functional receptor .

Transfectants grown in the presence of tetracycline contained about 15 , 000 receptors / cell , a value approximately equal to basal level <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in glucocorticoid - sensitive 6TG1.1 cells before steroid treatment .
Under these conditions , dexamethasone had a minimal effect on cell growth , elicited little internucleosomal DNA fragmentation , and induced no cell cycle perturbation .

In the absence of tetracycline , <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA and protein expression increased 2-3-fold , and cells expressed 48 , 000 receptors , a level nearly equivalent to that present in 6TG1.1 cells after 18 h of autoinduction .
Under these conditions , dexamethasone markedly inhibited cell growth , caused G1 arrest , and induced significant internucleosomal DNA fragmentation .

These studies therefore suggest that basal level <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression is inadequate to mediate glucocorticoid - induced apoptosis in glucocorticoid - sensitive T cells and that positive autoregulation is a necessary component of this process .
